OptionC: Persisting full ISO 20022 payloads as golden copy and using them as the primary source for AML and reporting even when MT is used operationally
OptionD: Converting everything to CSV and deleting XML
Correct: Persisting full ISO 20022 payloads as golden copy and using them as the primary source for AML and reporting even when MT is used operationally

Question: Which kind of field is most at risk of truncation when mapping ISO to MT
OptionB: Long structured postal addresses and detailed names
Correct: Long structured postal addresses and detailed names

Question: A bank participates in an RTGS that has migrated to ISO 20022 What is one direct impact on internal reporting
OptionA: Less information is available about high value payments
OptionB: More granular high value payment data from RTGS messages can be used in liquidity and intraday risk reports
Correct: More granular high value payment data from RTGS messages can be used in liquidity and intraday risk reports

Question: To reconcile RTGS ISO messages with internal records which identifier strategy is most robust
OptionA: Use free form references from RmtInf only
OptionB: Use a combination of RTGS message ids internal transaction ids and where available UETR as stable join keys
Correct: Use a combination of RTGS message ids internal transaction ids and where available UETR as stable join keys

Question: In Sibos case studies banks often report which practical obstacle when using ISO 20022 for AML
OptionA: Too few available fields in ISO
OptionB: Difficulty in improving upstream data quality so new ISO fields are consistently populated
OptionC: Inability to store XML in any database
Correct: Difficulty in improving upstream data quality so new ISO fields are consistently populated

Question: Where in MyStandards would you most likely find rules that a payments BA must respect when designing mappings
OptionB: In the Usage Rules that specify mandatory conditional and optional fields and valid value sets
OptionD: Nowhere because MyStandards is for network engineers only
Correct: In the Usage Rules that specify mandatory conditional and optional fields and valid value sets

Question: A bank defines its own stricter profile on top of CBPR plus in MyStandards What is the main reason
OptionA: To reduce message sizes for all counterparties
OptionB: To ensure all its counterparties send additional data it deems critical for risk and reporting
Correct: To ensure all its counterparties send additional data it deems critical for risk and reporting

Question: For cross border investigations why is UETR superior to relying solely on internal reference numbers
OptionA: It is shorter and easier to remember
OptionB: It is globally unique and carried across all hops so each bank can correlate messages for the same transaction even with different internal references
Correct: It is globally unique and carried across all hops so each bank can correlate messages for the same transaction even with different internal references

Question: A regulatory investigator wants every hop of a transaction that hit sanctions queues in three banks Which combination is most powerful to retrieve this
OptionB: UETR plus ISO message logs for pacs.008 pacs.009 and pacs.002 at each bank
Correct: UETR plus ISO message logs for pacs.008 pacs.009 and pacs.002 at each bank

Question: A bank case study shows they reduced sanctions false positives using ISO 20022 Which change most likely enabled this
OptionB: Replaced IBANs with random hashes
OptionC: Started using structured addresses and LEIs in screening engines rather than free text
Correct: Started using structured addresses and LEIs in screening engines rather than free text

Question: A CPMI report stresses cost transparency Which ISO data can be exploited to build cost metrics
OptionB: ChrgBr and fee related fields in ISO messages combined with amounts and corridors
Correct: ChrgBr and fee related fields in ISO messages combined with amounts and corridors

Question: To measure access improvements in cross border payments what ISO based indicator is most relevant
OptionB: Number of reachable corridors and counterparties based on BIC coverage and scheme participation
OptionD: Number of MT formats still in use
Correct: Number of reachable corridors and counterparties based on BIC coverage and scheme participation

Question: A new ECB reporting template adds a breakdown by sector and currency How can an ISO based warehouse adapt quickly
OptionB: By deriving sector from KYC for parties and using currency from ISO amounts then adjusting existing GROUP BY queries without changing ingestion
OptionD: By manually editing reports in Excel
Correct: By deriving sector from KYC for parties and using currency from ISO amounts then adjusting existing GROUP BY queries without changing ingestion

Question: In coexistence a mapping error drops UltmtDbtr during MT conversion Which regulatory report is most impacted
OptionB: Reports analyzing on behalf of flows and beneficial owner related risk
Correct: Reports analyzing on behalf of flows and beneficial owner related risk

Question: A central bank asks for statistics on large value cross border RTGS payments Which is the best ISO driven approach
OptionA: Use only pain.001 from retail channels
OptionB: Use RTGS ISO payment messages and enrich them with party residency and sector then aggregate by corridor and value bands
Correct: Use RTGS ISO payment messages and enrich them with party residency and sector then aggregate by corridor and value bands

Question: A Sibos session highlights improved investigation turnaround using ISO 20022 What technical change most likely underpinned this
OptionB: Using natural language processing only
OptionC: Centralising ISO payloads with searchable structured fields like UETR parties and corridors in an investigation tool
OptionD: Eliminating all logging to improve speed
Correct: Centralising ISO payloads with searchable structured fields like UETR parties and corridors in an investigation tool

Question: When building mappings in MyStandards which practice helps reduce downstream breakages
OptionA: Ignoring usage rules to stay flexible
OptionB: Treating all fields as optional
OptionC: Aligning table design and validations strictly with the combination of CBPR plus and bank specific usage rules
Correct: Aligning table design and validations strictly with the combination of CBPR plus and bank specific usage rules

Question: A bank wants to use ISO data to evidence speed improvements to regulators Which metric definition best fits
OptionA: Average report generation time in BI tool
OptionB: Median elapsed time from customer initiation to final pacs.002 accepted status per corridor and scheme
OptionC: Average number of staff in operations
OptionD: Average time to open a new account
Correct: Median elapsed time from customer initiation to final pacs.002 accepted status per corridor and scheme

Question: For balance of payments reporting which of the following combinations is most essential
OptionA: Customer names and GL account numbers only
OptionB: Amounts currencies residency of payer and payee and instrument type derived from ISO and KYC
Correct: Amounts currencies residency of payer and payee and instrument type derived from ISO and KYC

Question: A bank stores only final regulatory report files but no underlying ISO based snapshots What key capability is lost
OptionB: Ability to rerun and explain historical submissions using original transactional evidence
Correct: Ability to rerun and explain historical submissions using original transactional evidence

Question: To support Wolfsberg aligned correspondent banking dashboards which data source is most appropriate
OptionA: Only GL profit and loss accounts
OptionB: ISO 20022 fields for correspondents BICs intermediary agents corridors and volumes
Correct: ISO 20022 fields for correspondents BICs intermediary agents corridors and volumes

Question: An ISO based AML programme sets a KPI that 98 percent of cross border transactions must have structured addresses populated What risk does this KPI reduce
OptionB: Risk of poor sanctions matching due to missing location information
Correct: Risk of poor sanctions matching due to missing location information

Question: A JP Morgan VP asks how ISO 20022 helps respond faster to regulator queries Which answer is most convincing
OptionB: It allows storing and querying detailed structured transaction data by corridor party and purpose which makes ad hoc regulatory queries faster and more precise
OptionC: It replaces all need for MI teams
Correct: It allows storing and querying detailed structured transaction data by corridor party and purpose which makes ad hoc regulatory queries faster and more precise

Question: A Kafka topic carries payment_initiated events used by the regulatory warehouse A developer removes debtor_country from the event without coordinating What is the most likely impact
OptionA: No impact because the warehouse does not need country
OptionB: Downstream ETL and reports that rely on debtor_country will fail or silently mis report which is a breach of the data contract
OptionC: Only payment engine performance will improve
OptionD: Only BI dashboards will show more colours
Correct: Downstream ETL and reports that rely on debtor_country will fail or silently mis report which is a breach of the data contract

Question: A producer adds a new optional field aml_score with a default value to the Avro schema for payment_initiated What kind of change is this
OptionA: Backward compatible because old consumers can ignore aml_score
OptionB: Breaking change because new fields are always breaking
OptionC: Forward only compatible because old consumers cannot see it
OptionD: No change in schema versioning is required
Correct: Backward compatible because old consumers can ignore aml_score

Question: A consumer assumes Purp is always a valid ISO purpose code but producers sometimes send free text How does this violate the data contract
OptionB: It violates the agreed code list semantics and corrupts purpose based regulatory statistics
OptionD: It prevents any use of UETR
Correct: It violates the agreed code list semantics and corrupts purpose based regulatory statistics

Question: A team wants to run all BOE reports directly on the OLTP payment tables Which risk is highest
OptionB: The OLTP system may suffer performance degradation and locking issues affecting real time payments
OptionC: Regulators will receive data too fast
OptionD: Developers will have to write less SQL
Correct: The OLTP system may suffer performance degradation and locking issues affecting real time payments

Question: You are designing schemas for a write heavy CHAPS engine Which design is most appropriate
OptionA: Wide denormalized tables with no primary keys
OptionB: Normalized payment and ledger tables with strict constraints and focused indexes to ensure correctness and predictable performance
OptionC: Single huge table with all entities mixed
Correct: Normalized payment and ledger tables with strict constraints and focused indexes to ensure correctness and predictable performance

Question: A reporting team creates ad hoc tables with slightly different meanings for corridor than the canonical definition What is likely to happen
OptionB: Different reports may show conflicting corridor metrics undermining trust and regulatory confidence
Correct: Different reports may show conflicting corridor metrics undermining trust and regulatory confidence

Question: A fact_payment_reg table stores debtor_country only as a foreign key to dim_country without a copy column How can this affect performance
OptionB: Many reports will require extra joins to dim_country increasing query complexity and cost for common aggregations by debtor_country
OptionD: It will not compile on most databases
Correct: Many reports will require extra joins to dim_country increasing query complexity and cost for common aggregations by debtor_country

Question: You notice that customer risk_rating is stored only in dim_customer with SCD type 2 and not copied into the fact When a regulator asks for historical flows by risk bucket what is required
OptionA: Only current dim_customer needs to be joined
OptionB: The fact must join to the correct historical row in dim_customer for each payment using effective dates which is more complex than if a denormalized risk bucket were stored in the fact
OptionD: All historical data must be deleted
Correct: The fact must join to the correct historical row in dim_customer for each payment using effective dates which is more complex than if a denormalized risk bucket were stored in the fact

Question: A denormalized fact table stores customer_risk_bucket at load time but SCD logic is wrong and does not use effective dates What is the consequence
OptionA: Risk buckets will always be null
OptionB: Payments may be tagged with risk buckets that were not valid at the time of the transaction leading to incorrect retrospective risk reporting
Correct: Payments may be tagged with risk buckets that were not valid at the time of the transaction leading to incorrect retrospective risk reporting

Question: A new AML rule requires tracking ultimate beneficial owner country from ISO UltmtDbtr but the ingestion contract does not include that field What must be changed
OptionB: The ISO ingestion data contract and staging schemas must be updated and versioned to include UltmtDbtr fields and ETL extended accordingly
Correct: The ISO ingestion data contract and staging schemas must be updated and versioned to include UltmtDbtr fields and ETL extended accordingly

Question: Which schema design best supports both daily BOE reports and ad hoc corridor analysis on billions of rows
OptionA: Single OLTP payment table without partitioning
OptionB: Partitioned fact_payment_reg table with corridor and scheme columns plus supporting dimensions for flexible slicing
OptionC: Separate tables per corridor for each day
Correct: Partitioned fact_payment_reg table with corridor and scheme columns plus supporting dimensions for flexible slicing

Question: What happens if a producer sends numeric values in a string field that consumers treat as VARCHAR in the contract
OptionA: It is fine because strings can hold numbers
OptionB: Reports that do numeric aggregation may silently fail or require extra casting because the contract did not guarantee numeric type
Correct: Reports that do numeric aggregation may silently fail or require extra casting because the contract did not guarantee numeric type

Question: A warehouse team adds a NOT NULL constraint to debtor_country in fact_payment_reg without consulting upstream What is a likely side effect
OptionA: Messages with missing debtor_country will be rejected during load causing data loss or ETL failures
OptionB: OLTP will start failing
OptionD: Regulators will always get higher volumes
Correct: Messages with missing debtor_country will be rejected during load causing data loss or ETL failures

Question: Why is querying camt.053 statements alone insufficient for rich AML analysis compared to ISO payment facts
OptionA: Camt.053 contains all details about parties and corridors
OptionB: Camt.053 lines often lack full party and purpose details that ISO payment messages contain so AML rules would be under informed
Correct: Camt.053 lines often lack full party and purpose details that ISO payment messages contain so AML rules would be under informed

Question: A regulatory report relies on mapping BOE instrument types from several ISO fields Which practice reduces the risk of mis mapping
OptionA: Let each report define its own mapping logic
OptionB: Define a central instrument mapping contract and table used by all ETL and reports so mapping is consistent and versioned
OptionC: Ignore instrument type in data model
OptionD: Hard code instrument names in front end only
Correct: Define a central instrument mapping contract and table used by all ETL and reports so mapping is consistent and versioned

Question: A streaming producer changes currency field from three character codes to numeric ISO numbers without versioning What will consumers see
OptionB: They may interpret values as old codes causing nonsense currency values and broken reports
Correct: They may interpret values as old codes causing nonsense currency values and broken reports

Question: In OLTP a payment table is denormalized to include customer name and address Why is this risky
OptionA: It always improves performance and clarity
OptionB: It duplicates volatile customer data increasing chance of inconsistencies and making KYC changes harder to manage
OptionD: It stops isolation levels from working
Correct: It duplicates volatile customer data increasing chance of inconsistencies and making KYC changes harder to manage

Question: In OLAP a payment fact omits uetr and relies only on internal ids What investigation capability is lost
OptionB: Ability to join across banks and networks using UETR for cross border investigations and gpi tracking
Correct: Ability to join across banks and networks using UETR for cross border investigations and gpi tracking

Question: A report developer uses OLTP tables instead of the canonical warehouse to implement a BOE template What is the governance issue
OptionA: It is fine because data is fresher
OptionB: They bypass agreed contracts and lineage so definitions may differ and changes to OLTP could silently break the report
Correct: They bypass agreed contracts and lineage so definitions may differ and changes to OLTP could silently break the report

Question: Partitioning fact_payment_reg by booking_date but querying mostly by settlement_date leads to what effect
OptionB: Poor partition pruning and increased scan cost because most queries do not use the partition key in filters
Correct: Poor partition pruning and increased scan cost because most queries do not use the partition key in filters

Question: Which design best supports both current and future regulatory templates without major schema changes
OptionA: Design schemas exactly matching one current template
OptionB: Define a canonical model with generic payment attributes and derive templates through views so new reports reuse the same underlying tables
OptionC: Keep all data only in JSON columns
Correct: Define a canonical model with generic payment attributes and derive templates through views so new reports reuse the same underlying tables

Question: Why might duplicating debtor_country and corridor into fact_payment_reg be justified despite redundancy
OptionB: It simplifies queries and improves performance for the many reports that group and filter by those attributes
OptionC: It eliminates need for KYC data
Correct: It simplifies queries and improves performance for the many reports that group and filter by those attributes

Question: What is the main benefit of including data quality thresholds in a data contract
OptionB: They make it clear when missing or invalid data constitutes a breach that could impact regulatory reporting so issues are detected early
OptionD: They remove the need for tests
Correct: They make it clear when missing or invalid data constitutes a breach that could impact regulatory reporting so issues are detected early

Question: A new scheme rule changes valid Purp codes How should this be reflected in data contracts
OptionA: Ignore the change because Purp is free text
OptionB: Update central code lists and schema documentation and implement validation to reject or flag disallowed codes while versioning the contract
OptionC: Change database type from VARCHAR to INT only
Correct: Update central code lists and schema documentation and implement validation to reject or flag disallowed codes while versioning the contract

Question: What happens if an ETL job writes to both old and new fact tables but reports start using the new table before reconciliation
OptionB: Results may diverge from previous runs and inconsistencies could appear if dual write logic is faulty and not reconciled
Correct: Results may diverge from previous runs and inconsistencies could appear if dual write logic is faulty and not reconciled

Question: A consumer reads from payment_initiated_v1 and v2 without discriminating which version produced the event What is the risk
OptionA: No risk because versions are always compatible
OptionB: If v2 adds semantics or fields the consumer does not understand it may mis interpret data or miss new constraints
Correct: If v2 adds semantics or fields the consumer does not understand it may mis interpret data or miss new constraints

Question: Why should OLAP fact tables avoid business logic that depends on current time when computing regulatory attributes
OptionA: It makes facts easier to change later
OptionB: It can cause reported values to change over time for the same historical date breaking reproducibility and auditability
OptionD: It has no effect on reproducibility
Correct: It can cause reported values to change over time for the same historical date breaking reproducibility and auditability

Question: A dimension table is updated in place without SCD logic What problem can occur in regulatory reporting
OptionB: Historical reports that rely on attributes like sector or risk rating will silently change when the dimension updates losing the original context
OptionC: Less storage is used with no downside
Correct: Historical reports that rely on attributes like sector or risk rating will silently change when the dimension updates losing the original context

Question: How can contract tests help when evolving payment events feeding AML models
OptionA: They cannot help because models change often
OptionB: They ensure that key features such as amount corridor and party ids remain present and correctly typed so model inputs do not silently break when producers change
OptionC: They only test front end behaviour
Correct: They ensure that key features such as amount corridor and party ids remain present and correctly typed so model inputs do not silently break when producers change

Question: A golden copy ISO 20022 store is not maintained and only MT based tables feed regulatory reporting What is the consequence
OptionB: The bank loses access to rich ISO data such as structured addresses and ultimate parties limiting AML and regulatory analytics and making future requirements harder to meet
OptionC: Storage costs decrease but analytics improve
Correct: The bank loses access to rich ISO data such as structured addresses and ultimate parties limiting AML and regulatory analytics and making future requirements harder to meet

Question: Why is it dangerous to let every report define corridor logic independently
OptionB: Different definitions of corridor may produce inconsistent numbers for the same flows which regulators may view as control weakness
Correct: Different definitions of corridor may produce inconsistent numbers for the same flows which regulators may view as control weakness

Question: Which approach best handles a new mandatory BOE field that is a simple derivation of existing canonical columns
OptionB: Add a derived column or view in the reporting layer mapping from canonical fields leaving ingestion contracts unchanged
Correct: Add a derived column or view in the reporting layer mapping from canonical fields leaving ingestion contracts unchanged

Question: In designing fact_sanctions_hit what is the biggest risk of not including a foreign key to fact_payment_reg
OptionB: You cannot easily join hits to underlying payment attributes which limits analysis of corridors amounts and parties involved
Correct: You cannot easily join hits to underlying payment attributes which limits analysis of corridors amounts and parties involved

Question: Why must external BOE and EBA template changes feed into internal data contract governance
OptionB: Because new fields and definitions must be reflected in canonical schemas mappings and DQ rules else the bank risks mis reporting or manual patches
OptionC: Because templates are only for UI
Correct: Because new fields and definitions must be reflected in canonical schemas mappings and DQ rules else the bank risks mis reporting or manual patches

Question: What is the main benefit of using a semantic layer or data model between warehouse tables and BI tools
OptionB: It hides technical complexity and enforces consistent metric definitions and column meanings for all reports
OptionC: It eliminates the need for warehouses
OptionD: It avoids any need for data contracts
Correct: It hides technical complexity and enforces consistent metric definitions and column meanings for all reports

Question: A bank decides to store ISO fields only as JSON blobs in the warehouse without structured columns How does this affect regulatory reporting
OptionA: It makes ad hoc queries easier
OptionB: It complicates performance and governance because each report must parse JSON and definitions are hard to control and optimise
Correct: It complicates performance and governance because each report must parse JSON and definitions are hard to control and optimise

Question: Which design choice helps ensure reproducible regulatory reporting over time
OptionA: Using current dimensions for all joins
OptionB: Storing all necessary attributes in facts or via SCD joins as of the reporting date so reruns yield the same numbers
OptionD: Recomputing everything based on latest KYC only
Correct: Storing all necessary attributes in facts or via SCD joins as of the reporting date so reruns yield the same numbers

Question: According to SWIFT ISO 20022 for dummies what is the key benefit of using a common business model across markets
OptionB: It allows different communities to reuse the same concepts and messages improving interoperability and reducing bespoke mappings
OptionD: It eliminates all need for local rulebooks
Correct: It allows different communities to reuse the same concepts and messages improving interoperability and reducing bespoke mappings

Question: In the SWIFT ISO 20022 for dummies view which of the following is most accurate
OptionA: ISO 20022 only defines a syntax but no business meaning
OptionB: ISO 20022 provides both a business model and message schemas enabling consistent interpretation of data
OptionC: ISO 20022 is just a transport protocol
OptionD: ISO 20022 only applies to securities not payments
Correct: ISO 20022 provides both a business model and message schemas enabling consistent interpretation of data

Question: CBPR plus usage guidelines for pacs.008 primarily aim to
OptionA: Allow each bank to choose any field semantics they like
OptionB: Standardise how critical fields are populated in cross border payments to support routing compliance and analytics
OptionC: Reduce XML readability by removing comments
OptionD: Enforce only local language usage in free text
Correct: Standardise how critical fields are populated in cross border payments to support routing compliance and analytics

Question: Ignoring CBPR plus recommendations on structured addresses in cross border flows is risky because
OptionB: It can degrade sanctions screening and analytics by forcing systems to parse ambiguous free text
Correct: It can degrade sanctions screening and analytics by forcing systems to parse ambiguous free text

Question: Which statement about MyStandards and CBPR plus is correct
OptionA: MyStandards is only for storing PDFs
OptionB: MyStandards provides interactive CBPR plus message specs and testing tools that help banks implement ISO 20022 correctly
OptionD: MyStandards replaces all need for data modelling
Correct: MyStandards provides interactive CBPR plus message specs and testing tools that help banks implement ISO 20022 correctly

Question: The EPC SEPA Credit Transfer guidelines define that
OptionA: Any character set may be used
OptionB: All currencies are allowed
OptionC: Only euro is allowed and a restricted Latin character set must be used
OptionD: No constraints exist beyond ISO 20022 XSD
Correct: Only euro is allowed and a restricted Latin character set must be used

Question: For SEPA CT which charge bearer is allowed under EPC guidelines
OptionB: BEN only
OptionD: Any of OUR SHA or BEN
Correct: SHA only

Question: Compared with regular SEPA CT the SCT Inst scheme adds what critical requirement
OptionA: Payments must be done only during business hours
OptionB: Payments must be completed end to end within a strict time limit or be rejected
OptionD: Payments must always be in cash
Correct: Payments must be completed end to end within a strict time limit or be rejected

Question: To prove SCT Inst compliance what data becomes especially important
OptionB: Precise timestamps of initiation receipt processing and final confirmation events
Correct: Precise timestamps of initiation receipt processing and final confirmation events

Question: In FATF's digital transformation guidance what is the key advantage of structured customer data
OptionB: It allows rule engines and machine learning models to use consistent features such as country identifiers addresses and IDs improving detection and reducing noise
OptionC: It removes the need for sanctions lists
Correct: It allows rule engines and machine learning models to use consistent features such as country identifiers addresses and IDs improving detection and reducing noise

Question: FATF suggests that supervisors should
OptionA: Discourage use of standardised data formats
OptionB: Encourage institutions to leverage structured data and advanced analytics while maintaining sound risk management
Correct: Encourage institutions to leverage structured data and advanced analytics while maintaining sound risk management

Question: The Wolfsberg correspondent banking principles emphasise that banks should
OptionA: Avoid sharing information about underlying customers
OptionB: Have sufficient transparency into underlying customer transactions particularly for high risk corridors
OptionC: Rely only on SWIFT message length limits to control risk
Correct: Have sufficient transparency into underlying customer transactions particularly for high risk corridors

Question: How does pacs.009 COV align with Wolfsberg's emphasis on transparency
OptionA: By hiding all customer details from correspondents
OptionB: By providing or referencing underlying customer payment details in the cover payment enabling better due diligence
Correct: By providing or referencing underlying customer payment details in the cover payment enabling better due diligence

Question: CPMI identifies four main targets for improving cross border payments Which set is correct
OptionB: Risk capital liquidity leverage
Correct: Cost speed transparency access

Question: Which ISO 20022 feature most directly supports CPMI's transparency goal
OptionB: Use of UETR and structured party and charge data that can be shared end to end
OptionC: Use of compressed binary fields only
Correct: Use of UETR and structured party and charge data that can be shared end to end

Question: In CPMI reports how is the cost dimension for cross border payments typically measured
OptionB: By total CPU time on central systems
OptionC: By end user charges as a percentage of payment amount across corridors
OptionD: By number of staff in operations
Correct: By end user charges as a percentage of payment amount across corridors

Question: The Valcon case study argues against building each regulatory report separately because
OptionA: It is too easy to maintain
OptionB: It leads to multiple divergent data extracts and logic increasing risk of inconsistent numbers and missed deadlines
Correct: It leads to multiple divergent data extracts and logic increasing risk of inconsistent numbers and missed deadlines

Question: Valcon recommends which architectural approach for regulatory reporting
OptionA: Separate hand coded SQL per report
OptionB: One central integrated data warehouse and model feeding all reports
Correct: One central integrated data warehouse and model feeding all reports

Question: In the Diceus banking warehouse case the main driver for a new data warehouse was
OptionB: The bank needed consolidated timely data from many core systems for reporting and decision making
OptionC: The bank wanted to reduce disk space
OptionD: The bank had no ETL tools
Correct: The bank needed consolidated timely data from many core systems for reporting and decision making

Question: Diceus's solution to the bank's problem primarily involved
OptionA: Implementing a new core banking system only
OptionB: Creating a central data warehouse with ETL from multiple sources and pre built reporting capabilities
Correct: Creating a central data warehouse with ETL from multiple sources and pre built reporting capabilities

Question: In Martin Fowler's consumer driven contracts pattern who defines the key expectations in a contract
OptionB: Downstream consumers who specify what they rely on and which payload fields they need
Correct: Downstream consumers who specify what they rely on and which payload fields they need

Question: Why are consumer driven contracts particularly useful for data streaming in a bank
OptionB: They allow each consuming service to assert its requirements so producer changes can be tested against them preventing silent breakage
OptionC: They eliminate the need for schemas
OptionD: They are only for UI testing
Correct: They allow each consuming service to assert its requirements so producer changes can be tested against them preventing silent breakage

Question: What is a potential outcome if contracts between services are informal and not versioned as Fowler warns
OptionB: Integrations become brittle and changes may break downstream systems unexpectedly
Correct: Integrations become brittle and changes may break downstream systems unexpectedly

Question: From SWIFT ISO 20022 for dummies which of the following best describes why syntax translations alone are not enough
OptionA: Because XML is slower than SWIFT FIN
OptionB: Because maintaining mappings is cheaper than sharing a business model
OptionC: Because without shared business semantics different institutions may interpret the same field differently even if syntax matches
Correct: Because without shared business semantics different institutions may interpret the same field differently even if syntax matches

Question: CBPR plus mandates presence of UETR in many flows because
OptionB: It allows SWIFT gpi style end to end tracking and correlation of all legs of a cross border payment
Correct: It allows SWIFT gpi style end to end tracking and correlation of all legs of a cross border payment

Question: EPC guidelines limit the character set partly to
OptionB: Ensure compatibility across diverse back end and clearing systems and reduce errors when moving data through legacy platforms
OptionC: Allow free use of any script
Correct: Ensure compatibility across diverse back end and clearing systems and reduce errors when moving data through legacy platforms

Question: FATF's guidance on digital transformation implies which responsibility for banks
OptionB: Use structured standards like ISO 20022 responsibly to improve monitoring while managing model risk and explainability
OptionD: Avoid any analytics beyond rule based
Correct: Use structured standards like ISO 20022 responsibly to improve monitoring while managing model risk and explainability

Question: Wolfsberg suggests correspondents should understand which of the following about their respondents
OptionB: The types of underlying customers products and jurisdictions involved in the flows
Correct: The types of underlying customers products and jurisdictions involved in the flows

Question: CPMI suggests that better data will help central banks to
OptionB: Calibrate policies and oversight more effectively by understanding flows costs and frictions
Correct: Calibrate policies and oversight more effectively by understanding flows costs and frictions

Question: In Valcon's case a critical aspect of their data model was
OptionA: Designing separate schemas for every report
OptionB: Having a single version of truth for key measures such as outstanding balances and exposures
Correct: Having a single version of truth for key measures such as outstanding balances and exposures

Question: The Diceus warehouse case underscores what lesson about integrating new regulatory requirements
OptionA: You must always build a new bespoke data mart
OptionB: If the warehouse integrates core sources well new reports can often be delivered by adding mappings and views instead of new ingestion pipelines
OptionC: Regulatory compliance is separate from data architecture
OptionD: Warehouses should not be used for regulation
Correct: If the warehouse integrates core sources well new reports can often be delivered by adding mappings and views instead of new ingestion pipelines

Question: Martin Fowler notes that contracts work best when they are
OptionB: Explicit shared artefacts versioned and tested continuously
Correct: Explicit shared artefacts versioned and tested continuously

Question: Across CBPR plus EPC FATF and Wolfsberg documents what common requirement emerges for banks' data architectures
OptionB: Minimise stored data
OptionC: Be able to capture store and analyse richer structured payment data consistently across systems
Correct: Be able to capture store and analyse richer structured payment data consistently across systems

Question: What is a good indicator that a bank has successfully implemented CPMI's transparency objective using ISO 20022
OptionA: Customers must call support for each status update
OptionB: Customers and regulators can see payment status fees and routing through online tools powered by standardised UETR and charge data
OptionD: All messages are sent in proprietary formats
Correct: Customers and regulators can see payment status fees and routing through online tools powered by standardised UETR and charge data

Question: From the Valcon and Diceus stories what is a key architectural anti pattern for regulatory reporting
OptionB: Allowing each project to design separate data extracts and tables for similar metrics
Correct: Allowing each project to design separate data extracts and tables for similar metrics

Question: How might a bank use consumer driven contracts specifically for regulatory extract services
OptionA: By letting each report define how core systems must behave and validating changes against those expectations in CI
OptionB: By disabling all schemas
OptionC: By writing manual tests only for UI
Correct: By letting each report define how core systems must behave and validating changes against those expectations in CI

Question: What risk arises if CBPR plus usage rules are not reflected in internal data models
OptionA: No risk because models are independent
OptionB: Internal warehouses may omit fields that become de facto mandatory in the network leading to gaps in compliance and reporting
Correct: Internal warehouses may omit fields that become de facto mandatory in the network leading to gaps in compliance and reporting

Question: Why is it important to align CPMI metrics with canonical warehouse design
OptionA: To ensure metrics can be calculated directly from well defined fields such as fees timestamps and corridor rather than bespoke calculations per report
OptionB: To make schemas more complex
OptionD: To reduce the need for documentation
Correct: To ensure metrics can be calculated directly from well defined fields such as fees timestamps and corridor rather than bespoke calculations per report

Question: Taken together what do the FATF Wolfsberg and CPMI documents imply about the role of ISO 20022 in a future state architecture
OptionB: ISO 20022 should become a core data backbone providing structured fields that feed AML correspondent banking controls and macro reporting
OptionC: ISO 20022 cannot be used for compliance
OptionD: ISO 20022 must only be used in domestic flows
Correct: ISO 20022 should become a core data backbone providing structured fields that feed AML correspondent banking controls and macro reporting

Question: A Payment Engine team changes the `CurrencyCode` field from ISO 3-char to a numeric ID to optimize storage, breaking the downstream AML report. Which governance control failed?
OptionB: Schema Registry enforcement with Consumer-Driven Contract testing.
Correct: Schema Registry enforcement with Consumer-Driven Contract testing.

Question: You are designing a data warehouse for 2200 regulatory reports. Why is a Normalized (3NF) schema generally a poor choice for the Reporting Layer?
OptionA: It consumes too much storage space compared to Star Schema.
OptionB: It requires complex, multi-table joins to retrieve descriptive attributes, causing performance bottlenecks at scale.
OptionC: It creates data redundancy which leads to update anomalies.
OptionD: It does not support Foreign Keys.
Correct: It requires complex, multi-table joins to retrieve descriptive attributes, causing performance bottlenecks at scale.

Question: In a Star Schema for Payments, you have a `Dim_Customer`. A customer's Risk Rating changes from 'Low' to 'High'. You simply overwrite the existing record. What is the impact on regulatory reporting?
OptionA: Historical payments made when the customer was 'Low Risk' will now incorrectly report as 'High Risk', falsifying the audit trail.
OptionB: The report will fail to run due to a Primary Key violation.
OptionC: There is no negative impact; this is standard SCD Type 1 behavior.
Correct: Historical payments made when the customer was 'Low Risk' will now incorrectly report as 'High Risk', falsifying the audit trail.

Question: You need to ingest a high-throughput stream of `pacs.008` messages into a Data Lake. You need a format that supports schema evolution and is storage efficient. Which is the best choice?
OptionB: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation).
Correct: Avro (with Schema Registry).

Question: A regulator requires a report on 'Daily Failed Payments by Scheme'. The `Fact_Payment` table has 10 billion rows. Querying it directly is too slow. What is the best architectural solution?
OptionA: Create a Pre-Aggregated Summary Table (Materialized View) grouped by Scheme and Date.
OptionB: Add more indexes to every column in the Fact Table.
OptionC: Denormalize the Dimension tables into the Fact Table.
OptionD: Switch the database to 'Read Uncommitted' isolation level.
Correct: Create a Pre-Aggregated Summary Table (Materialized View) grouped by Scheme and Date.

Question: In a 'Dual-Write' scenario during ISO 20022 migration, the Payment Engine writes to both the Legacy MT table and the New MX table. The legacy table truncates the 'Ultimate Debtor' name. What is the risk?
OptionA: The system will crash due to disk space usage.
OptionB: Downstream AML screening will scan incomplete names, potentially missing sanctions hits.
OptionC: The MT messages will fail validation.
OptionD: The MX messages will be rejected by SWIFT.
Correct: Downstream AML screening will scan incomplete names, potentially missing sanctions hits.

Question: Which scenario represents a 'Breaking Change' in a Data Contract that uses Protobuf?
OptionB: Renaming an existing field that consumers rely on.
Correct: Renaming an existing field that consumers rely on.

Question: Why is 'OLTP' isolation (e.g., Serializable) generally bad for a 'Regulatory Reporting' query running on the same live database?
OptionB: It can block/lock the live payment rows, causing payment processing latency or timeouts.
OptionC: It makes the report run too fast.
Correct: It can block/lock the live payment rows, causing payment processing latency or timeouts.

Question: You are modelling a `Dim_Corridor` for reporting. Should `Corridor` (e.g., 'GBP-USD') be a separate dimension or an attribute on the Fact table?
OptionA: It must be a separate dimension to save space.
OptionB: If `Corridor` is a primary filter for 80% of reports and has low cardinality, storing it directly on the Fact table (degenerate dimension) improves performance.
OptionC: It should be calculated at query time to save storage.
OptionD: It should be stored in the Customer dimension.
Correct: If `Corridor` is a primary filter for 80% of reports and has low cardinality, storing it directly on the Fact table (degenerate dimension) improves performance.

Question: A Data Quality contract specifies `Completeness > 99%` for `BeneficiaryAddress`. The pipeline detects 5% nulls in the incoming batch. What should the automated response be?
OptionA: Drop the null rows and proceed.
OptionB: Auto-fill with 'UNKNOWN' and proceed.
OptionC: Halt the pipeline or route the batch to a 'DLQ/Quarantine' and alert the Data Steward immediately.
OptionD: Send an email and process the data anyway.
Correct: Halt the pipeline or route the batch to a 'DLQ/Quarantine' and alert the Data Steward immediately.

Question: Why is 'Partitioning by Transaction ID' usually a bad strategy for a Regulatory Reporting warehouse?
OptionB: Regulatory queries typically filter by Date ranges, not IDs, so Date partitioning enables 'Partition Pruning'. ID partitioning causes full table scans.
OptionC: It uses too much disk space.
OptionD: It makes the indexes too large.
Correct: Regulatory queries typically filter by Date ranges, not IDs, so Date partitioning enables 'Partition Pruning'. ID partitioning causes full table scans.

Question: You are implementing a 'Canonical Model' for payments. How do you map the legacy MT103 'Field 70' (Unstructured Remittance) vs ISO 20022 'Structured Remittance'?
OptionA: Discard the MT103 data as it is obsolete.
OptionB: Force ISO data into a single text column to match MT103.
OptionC: Create separate columns in the Canonical Model for `Remittance_Unstructured` and `Remittance_Structured` to preserve fidelity for both sources.
OptionD: Use a blob field for everything.
Correct: Create separate columns in the Canonical Model for `Remittance_Unstructured` and `Remittance_Structured` to preserve fidelity for both sources.

Question: What is the consequence of failing to implement 'Idempotency' in the ISO 20022 ingestion pipeline?
OptionB: If the producer resends a file due to a network glitch, the warehouse ingests duplicates, inflating regulatory volume figures.
Correct: If the producer resends a file due to a network glitch, the warehouse ingests duplicates, inflating regulatory volume figures.

Question: Why might you choose a 'Snowflake Schema' over a 'Star Schema' for the `Dim_Geography` (Country -> Region -> Continent) in a massive compliance database?
OptionB: To reduce data redundancy and ensure that if a Country changes Region, it is updated in only one place (Normalization).
OptionC: To make the diagrams look simpler.
Correct: To reduce data redundancy and ensure that if a Country changes Region, it is updated in only one place (Normalization).

Question: An auditor asks for the 'Lineage' of the 'Sanctions Hit' flag in a report. You have no metadata tool. What is the manual alternative?
OptionB: Tracing the SQL transformations code-by-code from the Report View back through Stored Procedures to the Source Table.
OptionC: Asking the developer who wrote it 5 years ago.
Correct: Tracing the SQL transformations code-by-code from the Report View back through Stored Procedures to the Source Table.

Question: In a microservices architecture, why is 'Database as an Interface' (sharing the OLTP DB with Reporting) considered an anti-pattern?
OptionA: It makes the database too large.
OptionB: It tightly couples the services; if the Payment Service refactors its internal schema, the Reporting Service breaks immediately.
OptionC: It prevents the use of SQL.
Correct: It tightly couples the services; if the Payment Service refactors its internal schema, the Reporting Service breaks immediately.

Question: A 'Late Arriving Dimension' issue occurs: A payment arrives referencing a new `SchemeID` that hasn't been loaded into `Dim_Scheme` yet. What is the best handling strategy?
OptionB: Delete the payment.
OptionC: Create a placeholder 'Unknown' or 'Inferred' record in `Dim_Scheme` with the new ID, allowing the fact to load, and update details later.
OptionD: Wait until the dimension load finishes.
Correct: Create a placeholder 'Unknown' or 'Inferred' record in `Dim_Scheme` with the new ID, allowing the fact to load, and update details later.

Question: What is the primary risk of using 'Select *' in a Data Contract or Reporting View?
OptionA: It is slower than selecting specific columns.
OptionB: If the source table adds a new column, the View might break or expose sensitive data (PII) unintentionally to consumers.
Correct: If the source table adds a new column, the View might break or expose sensitive data (PII) unintentionally to consumers.

Question: You are designing the contract for `pain.001` ingestion. The business says 'Amount' is mandatory. The XSD says it's optional (0..1). How do you configure the Data Contract?
OptionA: Follow the XSD and make it optional.
OptionB: Enforce the Business Rule: The Contract must reject any message without an Amount, even if the XSD allows it, to ensure data quality downstream.
Correct: Enforce the Business Rule: The Contract must reject any message without an Amount, even if the XSD allows it, to ensure data quality downstream.

Question: Why is 'Columnar Storage' (like Parquet) superior to 'Row-oriented Storage' (like Postgres Heap) for Regulatory Aggregation queries?
OptionB: It allows the query engine to read ONLY the `Amount` and `Currency` columns from disk, skipping all other columns, drastically reducing I/O.
OptionC: It is easier to update individual rows.
Correct: It allows the query engine to read ONLY the `Amount` and `Currency` columns from disk, skipping all other columns, drastically reducing I/O.

Question: If your Data Lake contains raw PII (Names, Addresses) from ISO 20022, how do you provide data to Data Scientists for 'Trend Analysis' without violating GDPR?
OptionA: Grant them full access but ask them to be careful.
OptionB: Delete the PII.
OptionC: Implement 'Dynamic Data Masking' or Tokenization in the access layer, so they see hashed values/asterisks instead of real names.
OptionD: Only give them data older than 1 year.
Correct: Implement 'Dynamic Data Masking' or Tokenization in the access layer, so they see hashed values/asterisks instead of real names.

Question: A Batch ETL job fails halfway through loading `Fact_Payment`. What property must the job have to ensure restarting it doesn't create duplicates?
OptionB: Idempotency (e.g., deleting the target date partition before inserting).
Correct: Idempotency (e.g., deleting the target date partition before inserting).

Question: In a 'Lambda Architecture', you have a Speed Layer (Real-time) and Batch Layer (History). A regulatory report requires 'Real-time + History'. What is the challenge?
OptionB: The 'Serving Layer' must merge the partial real-time view with the complete batch view, handling potential data overlaps/consistency issues.
Correct: The 'Serving Layer' must merge the partial real-time view with the complete batch view, handling potential data overlaps/consistency issues.

Question: What is the disadvantage of using 'JSON' fields inside a Relational Database for key ISO 20022 attributes?
OptionB: It forces the database to parse the JSON at query time (CPU intensive) and prevents efficient indexing of sub-fields unless 'Computed Columns' are used.
OptionD: It is not supported by SQL.
Correct: It forces the database to parse the JSON at query time (CPU intensive) and prevents efficient indexing of sub-fields unless 'Computed Columns' are used.

Question: How does a 'Surrogate Key' on `Dim_Customer` help with GDPR 'Right to be Forgotten'?
OptionB: It allows you to update the customer's PII in the Dimension table to 'Anonymized' while keeping the Fact table integrity (which links via the integer Key).
Correct: It allows you to update the customer's PII in the Dimension table to 'Anonymized' while keeping the Fact table integrity (which links via the integer Key).

Question: Why is 'Watermarking' important in a streaming payment pipeline?
OptionA: To mark the data as proprietary.
OptionB: To track event time progress and handle late-arriving data correctly for windowed aggregations (e.g., 'Hourly Payment Volume').
Correct: To track event time progress and handle late-arriving data correctly for windowed aggregations (e.g., 'Hourly Payment Volume').

Question: A query on `Fact_Payment` filters by `DebtorCountry`. The table is partitioned by `SettlementDate`. The query is slow. Why?
OptionB: The query cannot use 'Partition Pruning' because `DebtorCountry` is not the partition key, forcing a scan of all date partitions.
Correct: The query cannot use 'Partition Pruning' because `DebtorCountry` is not the partition key, forcing a scan of all date partitions.

Question: What is the main benefit of 'Contract Testing' in a CI/CD pipeline?
OptionA: It runs faster than unit tests.
OptionB: It verifies that the Provider's changes (e.g., new API version) match the Consumer's expectations (e.g., mocks) *before* deployment.
Correct: It verifies that the Provider's changes (e.g., new API version) match the Consumer's expectations (e.g., mocks) *before* deployment.

Question: You need to report on 'Payment Chains' (A -> B -> C). Your OLTP schema links them via `PreviousMessageID`. Why is a Recursive CTE (Common Table Expression) risky on a large dataset?
OptionB: It can lead to infinite loops or memory exhaustion if the chain is very deep or circular, crashing the reporting server.
Correct: It can lead to infinite loops or memory exhaustion if the chain is very deep or circular, crashing the reporting server.

Question: Which 'Data Type' choice is a common cause of financial rounding errors in reporting?
OptionB: Using `FLOAT` or `DOUBLE` (Floating Point) instead of Fixed Precision types.
Correct: Using `FLOAT` or `DOUBLE` (Floating Point) instead of Fixed Precision types.

Question: Why is 'Materialization' of views preferred over 'Virtual Views' for End-of-Day Regulatory Reports?
OptionB: Virtual views re-calculate the logic every time the report is opened; Materialized views pre-calculate and store the result, ensuring instant retrieval and consistency.
Correct: Virtual views re-calculate the logic every time the report is opened; Materialized views pre-calculate and store the result, ensuring instant retrieval and consistency.

Question: What is the primary function of a 'Data Catalog' in a large bank?
OptionB: To serve as a searchable inventory of data assets, definitions, ownership, and lineage, enabling discovery and governance.
Correct: To serve as a searchable inventory of data assets, definitions, ownership, and lineage, enabling discovery and governance.

Question: In a Star Schema, what is a 'Degenerate Dimension'?
OptionA: A dimension that has no data.
OptionB: A dimension attribute (like `InvoiceNumber` or `UETR`) that is stored directly in the Fact table because it has high cardinality and no other context.
OptionD: A dimension table with only one column.
Correct: A dimension attribute (like `InvoiceNumber` or `UETR`) that is stored directly in the Fact table because it has high cardinality and no other context.

Question: Why is 'Change Management' critical for 'Reference Data' (e.g., Country Codes, BIC Directory)?
OptionB: If a Country Code is removed (e.g., country split) but the historical data isn't handled, reports filtering by that code will become incomplete or invalid.
Correct: If a Country Code is removed (e.g., country split) but the historical data isn't handled, reports filtering by that code will become incomplete or invalid.

Question: What is the role of 'Taint Analysis' in Data Lineage?
OptionB: To trace how 'sensitive' or 'bad' data flows through the system to identify all downstream reports affected by a breach or quality issue.
Correct: To trace how 'sensitive' or 'bad' data flows through the system to identify all downstream reports affected by a breach or quality issue.

Question: When designing a 'Data Mesh', who owns the 'Payment Data Product'?
OptionB: The Payment Domain Team (Producers), who are responsible for the quality, contract, and availability of their data product.
Correct: The Payment Domain Team (Producers), who are responsible for the quality, contract, and availability of their data product.

Question: Why use 'Snapshot Isolation' for a long-running ETL extraction job on an OLTP source?
OptionA: It locks the table preventing updates.
OptionB: It provides a consistent view of the data as of the transaction start time, without blocking writers (using row versioning).
OptionD: It is faster than Read Uncommitted.
Correct: It provides a consistent view of the data as of the transaction start time, without blocking writers (using row versioning).

Question: A regulator demands to know why a specific transaction was flagged as 'High Risk'. Your AI model output is just a score. What architectural component is missing?
OptionB: Explainability / Model Governance logging (storing the feature vector inputs and SHAP values alongside the score).
Correct: Explainability / Model Governance logging (storing the feature vector inputs and SHAP values alongside the score).

Question: In a 'Kappa Architecture', how do you handle 'Reprocessing History' (e.g., bug fix in logic)?
OptionB: You run a separate batch job.
OptionC: You replay the historical events from the immutable log (Kafka) through the same real-time streaming pipeline.
Correct: You replay the historical events from the immutable log (Kafka) through the same real-time streaming pipeline.

Question: What is the risk of having 'Circular Dependencies' in your Data Pipeline (Table A builds Table B, which updates Table A)?
OptionB: It causes Deadlocks, infinite loops, and makes the pipeline impossible to schedule or backfill deterministically.
Correct: It causes Deadlocks, infinite loops, and makes the pipeline impossible to schedule or backfill deterministically.

Question: You are using Confluent Schema Registry with 'Backward Compatibility'. A producer team renames the mandatory field `PaymentAmount` to `Amt`. What happens?
OptionA: The Registry rejects the new schema registration because old consumers cannot read the new field `Amt`.
OptionB: The Registry accepts it, but consumers crash.
OptionC: The Registry automatically creates an alias.
OptionD: It works fine because Avro handles renaming.
Correct: The Registry rejects the new schema registration because old consumers cannot read the new field `Amt`.

Question: In a Kimball Star Schema for 'Daily Transaction Volume', you find that the 'Customer' dimension is growing too large (100 million rows) and slowing down ETL. What is the standard architectural fix?
OptionA: Denormalize the customer data into the Fact table.
OptionB: Implement a 'Mini-Dimension' for rapidly changing attributes (like Risk Score) and keep the main Customer dimension for static data.
Correct: Implement a 'Mini-Dimension' for rapidly changing attributes (like Risk Score) and keep the main Customer dimension for static data.

Question: You are designing a data contract for high-frequency trading payments (low latency). Why might you choose Protobuf over JSON?
OptionB: Protobuf schema validation is dynamic.
OptionC: Protobuf messages are significantly smaller (binary) and faster to deserialize, reducing network and CPU load.
Correct: Protobuf messages are significantly smaller (binary) and faster to deserialize, reducing network and CPU load.

Question: A `pacs.008` message ingestion pipeline is failing. The Data Contract specifies `UETR` is mandatory, but the Producer is sending NULL. The Producer claims the legacy source system doesn't have UETRs. What is the correct architectural resolution?
OptionB: The Producer must generate a synthetic UUID for these legacy payments *before* entering the pipeline to satisfy the contract.
OptionC: The Consumer should auto-generate the UETR.
Correct: The Producer must generate a synthetic UUID for these legacy payments *before* entering the pipeline to satisfy the contract.

Question: You are implementing a 'Data Mesh'. The 'Payment Operations' team exposes a raw, messy SQL table as a 'Data Product'. Why does this violate Mesh principles?
OptionA: Data Products must be 'Usable' and 'Valuable', implying the data should be cleaned, documented, and offered via a stable contract/interface, not just raw dump.
OptionB: Data Products must be JSON.
Correct: Data Products must be 'Usable' and 'Valuable', implying the data should be cleaned, documented, and offered via a stable contract/interface, not just raw dump.

Question: In a Delta Lake architecture (Medallion), a bug in the Silver Layer logic corrupted the `Risk_Score` for yesterday's data. How do you fix this using Delta features?
OptionA: Restore the database from a tape backup.
OptionB: Use `RESTORE TABLE ... TO VERSION AS OF ...` to roll back to the state before the bug, patch the code, and re-run the Silver job.
OptionC: Manually update the rows with SQL.
OptionD: Delete the table and re-ingest everything.
Correct: Use `RESTORE TABLE ... TO VERSION AS OF ...` to roll back to the state before the bug, patch the code, and re-run the Silver job.

Question: Your regulatory report requires 'Point-in-Time' reporting for Customer Addresses. You used SCD Type 1 (Overwrite) for the Address column. What is the consequence?
OptionA: The report will show the *current* address for a transaction that happened 2 years ago, potentially violating 'KYC at time of transaction' rules.
OptionB: The report will be slower.
OptionD: The database will grow too large.
Correct: The report will show the *current* address for a transaction that happened 2 years ago, potentially violating 'KYC at time of transaction' rules.

Question: A developer enables 'Compaction' on the Data Lake files while a heavy long-running Regulatory Report is reading them. What risk does this introduce if not handled by the Engine?
OptionA: The report will read duplicate data.
OptionB: The report might fail with a 'File Not Found' error if the engine doesn't support Multi-Version Concurrency Control (MVCC) / Snapshot Isolation.
Correct: The report might fail with a 'File Not Found' error if the engine doesn't support Multi-Version Concurrency Control (MVCC) / Snapshot Isolation.

Question: You are designing a Fact Table for 'Payment Status History'. A payment changes status 5 times (Pending -> Screening -> Approved -> Clearing -> Settled). Which Fact Table type is best for analyzing the time lag *between* steps?
OptionB: Periodic Snapshot Fact Table.
OptionC: Accumulating Snapshot Fact Table (one row per payment, multiple date columns updated as events happen).
Correct: Accumulating Snapshot Fact Table (one row per payment, multiple date columns updated as events happen).

Question: Why is 'Broadcast Join' preferred over 'Shuffle Join' when joining a large `Fact_Payment` with a small `Dim_Currency`?
OptionB: It replicates the small `Dim_Currency` table to every worker node, avoiding the massive network traffic of moving the `Fact_Payment` data.
OptionD: It only works for inner joins.
Correct: It replicates the small `Dim_Currency` table to every worker node, avoiding the massive network traffic of moving the `Fact_Payment` data.

Question: A Kafka Consumer Group for 'AML Screening' falls behind by 5 hours. What happens to the Real-Time requirements?
OptionB: The consumer is processing old data, meaning 'Real-Time' screening is effectively broken until it catches up. Latency increases.
Correct: The consumer is processing old data, meaning 'Real-Time' screening is effectively broken until it catches up. Latency increases.

Question: In a Star Schema, you have a `Dim_Date` table. Why populate it with 20 years of future dates?
OptionB: To allow for 'Future Dated Payments' to be loaded and queried without referential integrity failures.
Correct: To allow for 'Future Dated Payments' to be loaded and queried without referential integrity failures.

Question: You use 'Schema on Read' for your Data Lake. A producer changes the date format from `YYYY-MM-DD` to `DD-MM-YYYY`. What happens?
OptionB: The ingestion succeeds, but downstream queries fail or produce garbage dates at runtime (runtime error vs compile-time error).
Correct: The ingestion succeeds, but downstream queries fail or produce garbage dates at runtime (runtime error vs compile-time error).

Question: Why is 'Partitioning by High Cardinality Column' (e.g., `UETR`) a bad idea in a Data Lake (Parquet)?
OptionA: It makes looking up a single UETR fast.
OptionB: It creates millions of tiny files (Small File Problem), crushing the NameNode/Metadata server and slowing down listing/reading operations.
Correct: It creates millions of tiny files (Small File Problem), crushing the NameNode/Metadata server and slowing down listing/reading operations.

Question: A business user wants to analyze 'Payments by Month'. Your Fact Table is partitioned by `Date`. They run `SELECT * FROM Facts WHERE Month(Date) = 12`. Why is this query slow?
OptionA: It uses a function on the partition column, often preventing 'Partition Pruning' (depending on the DB engine), causing a full table scan.
OptionB: Months are hard to calculate.
Correct: It uses a function on the partition column, often preventing 'Partition Pruning' (depending on the DB engine), causing a full table scan.

Question: In dbt, you change the logic for a `Core_Payment` model. How do you ensure this doesn't break the downstream `Regulatory_Report` model?
OptionB: Use `dbt build` which runs tests on the modified model *and* its downstream dependencies before committing.
Correct: Use `dbt build` which runs tests on the modified model *and* its downstream dependencies before committing.

Question: You are designing a 'Global Payment' table. How do you handle Time Zones to ensuring accurate 'Cut-Off' reporting?
OptionB: Store everything in UTC, and have a `Dim_Timezone` or logic to convert to Local Time *only* at the presentation/reporting layer.
Correct: Store everything in UTC, and have a `Dim_Timezone` or logic to convert to Local Time *only* at the presentation/reporting layer.

Question: Why use 'Surrogate Keys' (Integers) instead of 'Natural Keys' (e.g., 34-char IBANs) for joins in the warehouse?
OptionA: Surrogate keys use less storage (4 bytes vs 34 bytes) and join significantly faster (CPU integer comparison vs string comparison).
OptionB: Natural keys are not unique.
OptionC: Surrogate keys are required by SQL.
Correct: Surrogate keys use less storage (4 bytes vs 34 bytes) and join significantly faster (CPU integer comparison vs string comparison).

Question: What is the risk of a 'Factless Fact Table' for 'Sanctions Checks' if it only logs 'Hits'?
OptionB: You cannot calculate the 'Percentage of Clean Payments' because you don't have the denominator (Total Checks).
Correct: You cannot calculate the 'Percentage of Clean Payments' because you don't have the denominator (Total Checks).

Question: In a Microservices architecture, the Payment Service emits a 'PaymentCreated' event. The Reporting Service consumes it. What pattern ensures the Reporting Service doesn't miss an event if it crashes?
OptionB: Durable Messaging / Log-based Broker (like Kafka) where the consumer tracks its own offset and can resume from where it left off.
Correct: Durable Messaging / Log-based Broker (like Kafka) where the consumer tracks its own offset and can resume from where it left off.

Question: You are archiving 10 years of payments to 'Cold Storage'. What file format is best for long-term storage and occasional analytics?
OptionB: Parquet or ORC (Columnar, compressed, schema-aware, widely supported).
Correct: Parquet or ORC (Columnar, compressed, schema-aware, widely supported).

Question: A `pacs.008` message has a 'Group Header' and multiple 'Transactions'. How do you model this in a Flat Fact Table?
OptionA: Create one row per Group Header.
OptionB: Create one row per Transaction, denormalizing (repeating) the Group Header attributes (like `MsgID`, `CreationDate`) onto each row.
Correct: Create one row per Transaction, denormalizing (repeating) the Group Header attributes (like `MsgID`, `CreationDate`) onto each row.

Question: What happens if you define a Data Contract with `strict` validation but the upstream system has poor data quality (50% bad records)?
OptionB: The pipeline will reject 50% of the data, potentially causing an operational incident (empty reports) unless a 'Quarantine' process is robust.
Correct: The pipeline will reject 50% of the data, potentially causing an operational incident (empty reports) unless a 'Quarantine' process is robust.

Question: Why is 'Change Data Capture' (CDC) on the Legacy Mainframe DB preferred over 'Daily Bulk Exports' for modern reporting?
OptionA: CDC provides near real-time data and reduces the load on the Mainframe (log reading vs full table scan).
OptionB: CDC is cheaper.
Correct: CDC provides near real-time data and reduces the load on the Mainframe (log reading vs full table scan).

Question: In a Data Mesh, a consumer team complains the 'Payment Data Product' is missing a field. Who is responsible for adding it?
OptionB: The Payment Domain Team (Producer). They must prioritize the feature request and update the product contract.
OptionC: The Consumer Team (they hack it in).
Correct: The Payment Domain Team (Producer). They must prioritize the feature request and update the product contract.

Question: You need to query a 10TB table for a single `TransactionID`. Which optimization technique is most critical?
OptionB: Bloom Filters / Z-Ordering / Indexing on `TransactionID` to allow the engine to skip 99.9% of the files.
Correct: Bloom Filters / Z-Ordering / Indexing on `TransactionID` to allow the engine to skip 99.9% of the files.

Question: What is the impact of 'Skewed Keys' (e.g., one 'Null' key for 50% of rows) when joining tables in Spark?
OptionB: It causes an 'OOM' (Out of Memory) error on the executor handling the 'Null' partition because all those rows are shuffled to the same node.
Correct: It causes an 'OOM' (Out of Memory) error on the executor handling the 'Null' partition because all those rows are shuffled to the same node.

Question: Why is 'ISO 20022 XML' generally converted to 'Parquet' or 'Avro' inside the Data Lake?
OptionB: XML parsing is CPU-intensive and not splittable. Parquet/Avro allow for parallel processing and schema enforcement.
Correct: XML parsing is CPU-intensive and not splittable. Parquet/Avro allow for parallel processing and schema enforcement.

Question: You have a 'Valid From' / 'Valid To' SCD Type 2 table. A user queries `WHERE Date = Today`. Why is this wrong?
OptionB: They should query `WHERE Today BETWEEN Valid_From AND Valid_To` to get the correct version of the record.
Correct: They should query `WHERE Today BETWEEN Valid_From AND Valid_To` to get the correct version of the record.

Question: In a 'Kappa Architecture', you want to fix a bug in the code that calculates 'Risk Score'. What do you do?
OptionB: Deploy the new code version, reset the Kafka Consumer Offset to the beginning of the retention period (or 0), and re-process the stream to overwrite/update the target table.
Correct: Deploy the new code version, reset the Kafka Consumer Offset to the beginning of the retention period (or 0), and re-process the stream to overwrite/update the target table.

Question: Why might you use a 'Graph Database' (Neo4j) alongside your Relational Warehouse for AML?
OptionB: Graph DBs are optimized for traversing deep relationships (Payment chains, Rings, Shared Addresses) which require expensive recursive joins in SQL.
Correct: Graph DBs are optimized for traversing deep relationships (Payment chains, Rings, Shared Addresses) which require expensive recursive joins in SQL.

Question: A Data Contract defines `Country` as an Enum [`US`, `GB`, `FR`]. The source sends `DE`. What happens in 'Strict' mode?
OptionB: The message is rejected to the DLQ.
Correct: The message is rejected to the DLQ.

Question: What is the 'Small File Problem' in Hadoop/Spark?
OptionA: Storing data in many files < 128MB (block size), causing excessive metadata overhead for the NameNode and slow read performance.
OptionB: Files are too small to read.
Correct: Storing data in many files < 128MB (block size), causing excessive metadata overhead for the NameNode and slow read performance.

Question: You are designing a 'Real-Time Dashboard'. Why query a Materialized View (Kafka Streams / KTable) instead of the raw stream?
OptionA: Raw streams are read-once; Views maintain the current state (aggregates) and can be queried interactively via REST/SQL.
OptionB: Views are slower.
Correct: Raw streams are read-once; Views maintain the current state (aggregates) and can be queried interactively via REST/SQL.

Question: Why is 'Referential Integrity' usually disabled (not enforced) in Data Warehouses (Snowflake/BigQuery)?
OptionB: Enforcing constraints during bulk loads is too expensive (performance). Instead, integrity is validated during the ETL/ELT pipeline logic.
Correct: Enforcing constraints during bulk loads is too expensive (performance). Instead, integrity is validated during the ETL/ELT pipeline logic.

Question: What is the benefit of 'Column-Level Encryption' over 'Disk Encryption' for payments?
OptionA: Disk encryption protects against physical theft. Column-level protects against authorized DBAs/Admins seeing sensitive PII (Cleartext) they don't need to see.
OptionB: It is faster.
Correct: Disk encryption protects against physical theft. Column-level protects against authorized DBAs/Admins seeing sensitive PII (Cleartext) they don't need to see.

Question: In an Event-Sourcing architecture, the 'Account Balance' is...
OptionB: A derived view calculated by replaying all 'Credit' and 'Debit' events for that account from the beginning of time (or from a snapshot).
Correct: A derived view calculated by replaying all 'Credit' and 'Debit' events for that account from the beginning of time (or from a snapshot).

Question: A 'Bridge Table' in your schema grows to 10 billion rows. Queries are slow. What is an alternative modeling strategy?
OptionB: Use an 'Array' or 'Map' data type in the Fact table (if the DB supports it, e.g., BigQuery/Snowflake) to store the list of values, avoiding the physical join.
Correct: Use an 'Array' or 'Map' data type in the Fact table (if the DB supports it, e.g., BigQuery/Snowflake) to store the list of values, avoiding the physical join.

Question: Why is 'Exact-Once Semantics' (EOS) difficult in distributed stream processing?
OptionB: It requires coordination between the consumer offsets and the output sink (e.g., Transactional Kafka or Idempotent Writes) to ensure a crash doesn't cause a double-write.
Correct: It requires coordination between the consumer offsets and the output sink (e.g., Transactional Kafka or Idempotent Writes) to ensure a crash doesn't cause a double-write.

Question: Your contract states `Amount` is `Decimal(10,2)`. A Hyper-Inflation currency payment arrives requiring 12 digits. What happens?
OptionA: Precision Loss or Overflow Error. The contract must be designed with 'Max Theoretical Size' (e.g., `Decimal(28,2)`) in mind for global payments.
OptionB: It works fine.
Correct: Precision Loss or Overflow Error. The contract must be designed with 'Max Theoretical Size' (e.g., `Decimal(28,2)`) in mind for global payments.

Question: A UK customer pays an online invoice in GBP using their bank app and the beneficiary sees funds within seconds Which rail is most likely used
OptionA: A BACS payment submitted for the next working day
OptionB: A Faster Payments transfer executed in near real time
OptionC: An international SWIFT wire routed through CHAPS
OptionD: A SEPA Direct Debit collected from their account
Correct: A Faster Payments transfer executed in near real time

Question: A merchant receives authorization approval for a card purchase but later the clearing file fails to include the transaction What is the most likely impact
OptionA: The customer is billed twice automatically
OptionB: The merchant may never receive funds because the transaction does not appear in clearing and settlement
OptionC: The issuer will always guarantee payment regardless of clearing
OptionD: The card network automatically resends all missing items without any process
Correct: The merchant may never receive funds because the transaction does not appear in clearing and settlement

Question: A bank needs to pay salaries to fifty thousand employees with value date tomorrow Which rail is usually most appropriate
OptionA: Real time FPS for every salary item
OptionB: ACH or BACS batch credit transfer for the payroll file
OptionC: UPI instant payments for each employee
OptionD: Individual card credits using CNP card transactions
Correct: ACH or BACS batch credit transfer for the payroll file

Question: In a CNP card transaction the main reason to use 3D Secure is to
OptionB: Reduce fraud and shift liability toward the issuer by strongly authenticating the cardholder
OptionC: Speed up POS chip and PIN flows
OptionD: Avoid using card networks for routing
Correct: Reduce fraud and shift liability toward the issuer by strongly authenticating the cardholder

Question: A customer in the EEA initiates an online card payment to a merchant in their home country under PSD2 When is SCA most likely required
OptionA: Always for any transaction below one euro
OptionB: For most electronic card payments unless a specific exemption applies such as low value or trusted beneficiary
Correct: For most electronic card payments unless a specific exemption applies such as low value or trusted beneficiary

Question: A bank is designing an instant refund process for an ecommerce marketplace Which rail is generally best suited
OptionB: Card chargebacks exclusively
OptionC: Real time account to account rail such as FPS or FedNow
Correct: Real time account to account rail such as FPS or FedNow

Question: Which scenario best illustrates a push payment
OptionA: A merchant charging a saved card after subscription renewal
OptionB: A biller initiating a SEPA Direct Debit from a customer account
OptionC: A customer sending money via online banking to a friend account using FPS
OptionD: An acquirer submitting a clearing file to a card network
Correct: A customer sending money via online banking to a friend account using FPS

Question: Which scenario best illustrates a pull payment
OptionA: A customer sending funds via UPI to a merchant QR code
OptionB: A customer withdrawing cash from an ATM
OptionC: A utility company collecting monthly amounts via direct debit under a signed mandate
OptionD: A bank sending a wire on behalf of a corporate
Correct: A utility company collecting monthly amounts via direct debit under a signed mandate

Question: A bank wants to reduce the impact of a potential card database breach at a large merchant What technique is most appropriate
OptionB: Using tokenization so that merchants store tokens instead of PANs
OptionC: Storing PANs in plain text with stronger firewalls
OptionD: Switching all traffic to batch ACH
Correct: Using tokenization so that merchants store tokens instead of PANs

Question: A CNP transaction passes 3DS authentication but is later found to be fraudulent What is the usual liability position under scheme rules
OptionA: The issuer often bears liability after successful 3DS because the cardholder was authenticated
OptionB: The merchant always bears liability regardless of 3DS
